articles.title: The introduction of the euro in Bulgaria is not related to an increase in inflation, according to an analysis by the Fiscal Council
articles.summary: The feeling of a general increase in prices is often more psychological than real, the analysis states
articles.content:
The feeling of a general increase in prices is often more psychological than real, the analysis states

SOFIA – The introduction of the euro is a nominal change and is not related to an increase in inflation, according to the Fiscal Council of Bulgaria in an analysis examining the level of inflation in several eurozone countries three years before and three years after the introduction of the euro.

Inflation is not caused by the currency change itself, but by real factors such as military conflicts with direct impact on the country, production costs, demand, energy prices and economic policy, the Fiscal Council points out.

Prices and incomes in the country were recalculated at the fixed exchange rate and this did not lead to an increase in the money supply, all the more so since our country was also under a currency board arrangement. The experience of the eurozone countries shows only a minimal one-off effect, and the perception of a general increase in prices (inflation) is often more psychological than real, the analysis further states.

The Fiscal Council notes that before the introduction of the euro there was a moderate to strong increase in inflation in the countries under review and more specifically – strong in Estonia, negative to moderate in Latvia, and moderate in Slovenia, Slovakia and Croatia.

In the first year after the introduction of the euro, inflation increased in three countries – Slovenia (+1.3%), Estonia (+2.4%) and Latvia (+0.7%). In three countries inflation decreased – Slovakia (-3.0%), Lithuania (-0.9%) and Croatia (-2.1%).

In the second and third year after the introduction there is stabilization and a return to moderate levels in all six countries.

As of 1 January 2026 Bulgaria is officially the 21st member of the eurozone. On 8 July 2025 the Council of the EU unanimously voted on the final decisions related to the adoption of the euro in the country. This completed the procedure, after earlier the same day the European Parliament also approved by a large majority the report on the introduction of the single European currency by Bulgaria. (26.01.2026)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant economic policy change—the introduction of the euro in Bulgaria—and provides an analysis showing it does not cause inflation increases. This helps reduce public anxiety and supports economic stability, benefiting the general population. The story is focused, detailed, and has broad societal impact.
articles.personality_title: Analysis shows euro adoption in Bulgaria won’t raise inflation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria is set to join the eurozone and start using the euro currency on January 1, 2026. Many people worry that switching to the euro will cause prices to rise and make everyday goods more expensive.

**What happened** – The Fiscal Council of Bulgaria studied inflation in six countries that adopted the euro in recent years. They looked at inflation rates three years before and three years after these countries changed their currency. Their analysis found no clear link between switching to the euro and long-term price increases.

**Impact** – The study shows that inflation changes are caused by real economic factors like energy prices, conflicts, or demand—not just changing the currency. The feeling that prices jump right after adopting the euro is often more about perception than reality. This finding helps reduce public fears and supports trust in Bulgaria’s upcoming currency change.

**What's next step** – Bulgaria will officially join the eurozone in 2026. Authorities and businesses will continue preparing to ensure a smooth transition. The Fiscal Council’s analysis may guide communication efforts to keep people informed and calm about what to expect.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Switching to the euro does not cause inflation to rise, and Bulgaria’s upcoming change is unlikely to make prices go up significantly.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’adoption de l’euro en Bulgarie n’entraînera pas d’augmentation de l’inflation, selon une analyse
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Bulgarie doit rejoindre la zone euro et utiliser l’euro à partir du 1er janvier 2026. Beaucoup craignent que ce changement de monnaie fasse augmenter les prix des biens quotidiens.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le Conseil fiscal bulgare a étudié l’inflation dans six pays ayant adopté l’euro récemment. Ils ont comparé les taux d’inflation trois ans avant et trois ans après le passage à l’euro. Leur analyse montre qu’il n’y a pas de lien clair entre le changement de monnaie et une hausse durable des prix.

**Impact** – L’étude montre que les variations d’inflation sont liées à des facteurs économiques réels comme le prix de l’énergie, les conflits ou la demande, pas seulement au changement de monnaie. La sensation d’une hausse des prix juste après l’adoption de l’euro est souvent plus psychologique que réelle. Ces résultats aident à calmer les inquiétudes du public et renforcent la confiance dans ce changement.

**Prochaine étape** – La Bulgarie rejoindra officiellement la zone euro en 2026. Les autorités et les entreprises continueront à se préparer pour assurer une transition sans problème. L’analyse du Conseil fiscal pourra aider à mieux informer et rassurer la population.

**Phrase clé** – Passer à l’euro ne fait pas augmenter l’inflation, et le changement prévu en Bulgarie ne devrait pas entraîner une hausse significative des prix.
articles.personality_title_es: El análisis muestra que la adopción del euro en Bulgaria no aumentará la inflación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria se prepara para unirse a la zona euro y comenzar a usar el euro el 1 de enero de 2026. Muchas personas temen que cambiar la moneda provoque un aumento en los precios de los productos diarios.

**Qué pasó** – El Consejo Fiscal de Bulgaria estudió la inflación en seis países que adoptaron el euro en años recientes. Analizaron las tasas de inflación tres años antes y tres años después del cambio de moneda. Su análisis no encontró una relación clara entre adoptar el euro y un aumento duradero de los precios.

**Impacto** – El estudio muestra que los cambios en la inflación se deben a factores económicos reales como el precio de la energía, conflictos o la demanda, no solo al cambio de moneda. La sensación de que los precios suben justo después de adoptar el euro suele ser más psicológica que real. Esto ayuda a reducir el miedo público y genera confianza en el cambio próximo en Bulgaria.

**Próximo paso** – Bulgaria se unirá oficialmente a la zona euro en 2026. Las autoridades y empresas seguirán preparándose para que la transición sea suave. El análisis del Consejo Fiscal puede ayudar a informar mejor y tranquilizar a la población.

**Frase clave** – Cambiar al euro no causa que la inflación suba, y el cambio en Bulgaria probablemente no aumentará significativamente los precios.

articles.title: EU4Culture, cuisine highlights the hidden heritage of Kurbin in Albania
articles.summary: The purpose of the project was simple but essential: to bring to light the hidden heritage of Kurbin by connecting tradition with skills, community, and sustainable tourism.
articles.content:
The purpose of the project was simple but essential: to bring to light the hidden heritage of Kurbin by connecting tradition with skills, community, and sustainable tourism.

Kurbini is an area in Albania from which visitors take with them impressions not only of what they see there but also of those they meet: generous, simple people who carry their heritage into everyday life.

Part of this heritage is also the cuisine, which has recently become the subject of the project “Timeless Tastes: Indulge into the flavours and ballads of Kurbin”, implemented by the Albanian Local Capacity Development Foundation (ALCDF) within the framework of the EU4Culture program.

The aim of the project was simple but essential: to bring to light the hidden heritage of Kurbin by connecting tradition with skills, the community and sustainable tourism.

At the center of this journey stands Dhurata Thanasi, culinary entrepreneur and food activist. She entered the kitchens, gardens and family yards, precisely where different generations came together; grandmothers, mothers and young people, sharing recipes, memories and knowledge passed down from generation to generation.

The project also brought the publication by ALCDF, “The Kurbin Recipe Book”, valuing the knowledge, creativity and empowerment of local women. EU4Culture stated on social networks that such initiatives connect tradition, skills and sustainable tourism, creating spaces where culture and community come together. (26 January)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a meaningful cultural heritage project that highlights and preserves the hidden traditions and cuisine of Kurbin, Albania, connecting community, skills, and sustainable tourism. It has a positive real-world impact by empowering local women, promoting cultural preservation, and fostering sustainable tourism, which benefits the broader community and society. The story is focused and provides sufficient context about the project's goals and outcomes.
articles.personality_title: Kurbin’s hidden heritage shines through food and tradition
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Kurbin is a region in Albania known for its welcoming people and rich cultural traditions. Many of these traditions, especially in local cooking, have been passed down through families but remain largely unknown to visitors.

**What happened** – A project called “Timeless Tastes: Indulge into the flavours and ballads of Kurbin” was launched by the Albanian Local Capacity Development Foundation (ALCDF) as part of the EU4Culture program. Led by culinary entrepreneur Dhurata Thanasi, it brought together grandmothers, mothers, and young people to share recipes, stories, and cooking skills. The project also published “The Kurbin Recipe Book” to celebrate local women’s knowledge and creativity.

**Impact** – This project highlights Kurbin’s hidden heritage by connecting traditional cooking with community life and sustainable tourism. It empowers local women by valuing their skills and stories, while encouraging visitors to experience culture in a meaningful way. The recipe book helps preserve these traditions for future generations.

**What’s next step** – With the recipe book and community connections established, the project may inspire more sustainable tourism in Kurbin. It could also encourage other regions to explore and promote their own cultural heritage through similar initiatives.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A project in Kurbin, Albania, uses traditional cooking and community stories to preserve hidden heritage and support sustainable tourism.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le patrimoine caché de Kurbin révélé à travers la cuisine et la tradition
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Kurbin est une région d'Albanie connue pour ses habitants accueillants et ses riches traditions culturelles. Beaucoup de ces traditions, notamment en cuisine locale, se transmettent de génération en génération mais restent peu connues des visiteurs.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un projet appelé « Saveurs intemporelles : plongez dans les goûts et les ballades de Kurbin » a été lancé par la Fondation albanaise pour le développement des capacités locales (ALCDF) dans le cadre du programme EU4Culture. Dirigé par l’entrepreneuse culinaire Dhurata Thanasi, il a réuni grand-mères, mères et jeunes pour partager recettes, histoires et savoir-faire. Le projet a aussi publié « Le livre de recettes de Kurbin » pour célébrer les connaissances et la créativité des femmes locales.

**Impact** – Ce projet met en lumière le patrimoine caché de Kurbin en reliant la cuisine traditionnelle à la vie communautaire et au tourisme durable. Il valorise les compétences et les récits des femmes locales tout en invitant les visiteurs à vivre la culture de façon authentique. Le livre de recettes aide à préserver ces traditions pour les générations futures.

**Prochaine étape** – Avec le livre de recettes et les liens communautaires établis, le projet pourrait encourager un tourisme durable accru à Kurbin. Il pourrait aussi inspirer d’autres régions à valoriser leur propre patrimoine culturel par des initiatives similaires.

**Une phrase clé** – Un projet à Kurbin, en Albanie, utilise la cuisine traditionnelle et les histoires locales pour préserver un patrimoine caché et soutenir un tourisme durable.
articles.personality_title_es: El patrimonio oculto de Kurbin brilla a través de la comida y la tradición
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Kurbin es una región de Albania conocida por su gente amable y sus ricas tradiciones culturales. Muchas de estas tradiciones, especialmente en la cocina local, se han transmitido de generación en generación pero son poco conocidas por los visitantes.

**Qué pasó** – Se lanzó un proyecto llamado “Sabores eternos: disfruta los sabores y baladas de Kurbin” por la Fundación Albanesa para el Desarrollo de Capacidades Locales (ALCDF) dentro del programa EU4Culture. Liderado por la emprendedora culinaria Dhurata Thanasi, reunió a abuelas, madres y jóvenes para compartir recetas, historias y habilidades culinarias. El proyecto también publicó “El libro de recetas de Kurbin” para valorar el conocimiento y la creatividad de las mujeres locales.

**Impacto** – Este proyecto destaca el patrimonio oculto de Kurbin al conectar la cocina tradicional con la vida comunitaria y el turismo sostenible. Empodera a las mujeres locales al valorar sus habilidades y relatos, mientras invita a los visitantes a experimentar la cultura de manera auténtica. El libro de recetas ayuda a preservar estas tradiciones para las futuras generaciones.

**Próximo paso** – Con el libro de recetas y las conexiones comunitarias establecidas, el proyecto podría inspirar un aumento del turismo sostenible en Kurbin. También podría motivar a otras regiones a explorar y promover su propio patrimonio cultural mediante iniciativas similares.

**Una frase clave** – Un proyecto en Kurbin, Albania, usa la cocina tradicional y las historias comunitarias para preservar un patrimonio oculto y apoyar el turismo sostenible.
